across.text: In position with weapons for military command
across.explanation: PRESENT ARMS(i.e. a “military command”). Solution is PRESENT (i.e. attending or “in position”) followed by ARMS (i.e. “weapons”).

across.text: Say what I saw and heard, naked man in court
across.explanation: BEAR WITNESS(i.e. “say what I saw”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “heard”) of BARE (i.e. “naked”) followed by WITNESS (i.e. “man in court”).

across.text: No piffling oration broadcast, but something of enduring value
across.explanation: INFLATION-PROOFING(i.e. “of enduring value”). “Broadcast” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of NO PIFFLING ORATION.

across.text: Fields for example almost all next to sea
across.explanation: MEDAL(i.e. “Fields for example”, apparently a medal awarded to mathematicians under the age of 40 for outstanding contributions to the field. No, me neither). Solution is ALL with the last letter removed (indicated by “almost”) and the remainder placed after or “next to” MED (i.e. “sea”, short for Mediterranean), like so: MED-AL.

across.text: Macbeth’s life a brief one, but a measure of certain intensity
across.explanation: CANDLE. Solution satisfies Lady “Macbeth’s life a brief one”, referencing a line from The Scottish Play, and “a measure of certain intensity”, specifically of light.

across.text: Heavenly group beg one to interrupt less regularly
across.explanation: PLEIADES(i.e. “heavenly group”, a constellation you see in Jumbos suspiciously more than others). Solution is PLEAD (i.e. “beg”) wrapped around or “interrupted” by I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and followed by ES (i.e. “less regularly”, i.e. every other letter of LESS), like so: PLE(I)AD-ES.

across.text: Material can appeal to the left, and in France to the right
across.explanation: SATINET(i.e. “material”). Solution is TIN (i.e. “can”) with SA (i.e. “appeal”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of Sex Appeal I’ve only ever seen used in cryptic crosswords) placed “to the left” of it, and ET (i.e. “and in France”, i.e. the French for “and”) placed “to the right” of it, like so: SA-(TIN)-ET. One nailed from the wordplay, to be honest.

across.text: Excellent month with a brilliant sight
across.explanation: SUPERNOVA(i.e. “brilliant sight”, as in being a bit on the bright side). Solution is SUPER (i.e. “excellent”) followed by NOV (i.e. “month”, short for November) and A.

across.text: Bond linking animal to one insect
across.explanation: ASSIGNAT(i.e. “bond” – over the Chambers: “one of the paper bonds first issued in 1789 by the French government on the security of the appropriated church lands, and later (1790-97) accepted as notes of currency”. A modern everyday term, then. Righto). Solution is ASS (i.e. “animal”) followed by I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and GNAT (i.e. “insect”).

across.text: Jump out of plane tree in the end
across.explanation: JETE(i.e. “jump” – and again to Chambers: “a leap from one foot to the other in which the free leg usually finishes extended forward, backwards or sideways”. If you were in any doubt that this week’s setter has wilfully gone heavy on the general knowledge, consider how many other words could have fitted the letters _E_E). Solution is JET (i.e. “plane”) followed by E (i.e. “tree in the end”, i.e. the last letter of “tree”).

across.text: Indian sage’s last to lead islanders
across.explanation: IRISH(i.e. “islanders”). Solution is RISHI (i.e. an “Indian sage” or poet) with the “last” letter placed first or “to lead”, like so: RISH(I) => (I)RISH.

across.text: Odds on at first, nonetheless
across.explanation: EVEN SO(i.e. “nonetheless”). Solution is EVENS (i.e. “odds”) followed by O (i.e. “on at first”, i.e. the first letter of “on”).

across.text: Water and a leek vegan digested
across.explanation: LAKE GENEVA(i.e. a body of “water”). “Digested” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of A LEEK VEGAN.

across.text: Sweet ban rejected: a handout all round
across.explanation: ADORABLE(i.e. “sweet”). Solution is BAR (i.e. “ban”) reversed (indicated by “rejected”) and placed in or having “all round” A and DOLE (i.e. “handout”), like so: A-DO(RAB)LE.

across.text: They distrust all sportsmanship: it flourished only without pressure
across.explanation: MISANTHROPISTS(i.e. “they distrust all”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “flourished”) of SPORTSMANSHIP IT once one of the Ps has been removed (indicated by “without pressure” – P being a recognised abbreviation of “pressure”).

across.text: Baronet is concealing difficult time, old flame discovered
across.explanation: BROUGHT TO LIGHT(i.e. “discovered”). Solution is BT (a recognised abbreviation of “baronet”) wrapped around or “concealing” ROUGH (i.e. “difficult”) and T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”), and followed by O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) then LIGHT (i.e. “flame”), like so: B(ROUGH-T)T-O-LIGHT.

across.text: In Rome, building stone dries up, but not out
across.explanation: ST PETERSBasilica (i.e. “in Rome, building”). Solution is ST (a recognised abbreviation of “stone”) followed by PETERS (i.e. “dries up, but not out”, i.e. peters out with the “out” removed).

across.text: Soldiers love armoured vehicles to capture so-called German
across.explanation: OTHER RANKS(i.e. some “soldiers” of the British Army – often you’ll see its abbreviation, OR, used in cryptic crosswords). Solution is O (i.e. “love”, a zero score in tennis) followed by TANKS (i.e. “armoured vehicles”) once wrapped around or “capturing” HERR (i.e. “so-called German”, a form of address), like so: O-T(HERR)ANKS.

across.text: Heart is troublesome, somewhat, for performer
across.explanation: ARTIST(i.e. “performer”). “Somewhat” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: HE(ART IS T)ROUBLESOME.

across.text: Captain engaging Mike to do a rush job
across.explanation: SKIMP(i.e. “to do a rush job”). Solution is SKIP (i.e. “captain”, short for skipper) wrapped around or “engaging” M (“Mike” in the phonetic alphabet), like so: SKI(M)P.

across.text: In inaccessible place I lost Jane
across.explanation: EYRE(i.e. “Jane”, eponymous heroine of Charlotte Brontë’s novel). Solution is EYRIE (i.e. a high or “inaccessible place”) with the I removed (indicated by “I lost”).

across.text: Artist and minor comic
across.explanation: PietMONDRIAN(i.e. “artist” – again, me neither). “Comic” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of AND MINOR.

across.text: A “dispiriting” worker, tax inspector finally traps men
across.explanation: EXORCISER(i.e. “a ‘dispiriting’ worker”, playfully taking the word to mean the removal of spirit from something). Solution is EXCISE (i.e. “tax”) and R (i.e. “inspector finally”, i.e. the last letter of “inspector”) all wrapped around OR (i.e. “men”, specifically the Other Ranks we encountered in 38a), like so: EX(OR)CISE-R.

across.text: Wounded hare – it’s less speedy?
across.explanation: HASTIER(i.e. “less speedy” – I guess this is playing on the phrase “more haste, less speed”, replacing “haste” and “speed” with the comparative adverbs HASTIER and “speedier”). “Wounded” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of HARE IT’S.

across.text: Angry way we must enter lawless zone
across.explanation: WILD WEST(i.e. “lawless zone”). Solution is WILD (i.e. “angry”) and ST (i.e. “way”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “street”) wrapped around or having “entered” WE, like so: WILD-(WE)-ST.

across.text: Hard work with a new catchphrase
across.explanation: SLOGAN(i.e. “catchphrase”). Solution is SLOG (i.e. “hard work”) followed by A and N (a recognised abbreviation of “new”).

across.text: A poem in part of cell
across.explanation: ANODE(i.e. “part of cell” – and once more to Chambers: “the electrode of an electrolytic cell by which current enters the electrolyte or gas”). When written as AN ODE the solution also satisfies “a poem”. Another nailed solely from the wordplay.

across.text: Most substantial course is something involving blackbirds? Allow opposition
across.explanation: PIECE DE RESISTANCE(i.e. “most substantial course”, perhaps delivered with a chef’s kiss). Solution is PIE (i.e. “something involving blackbirds”, after the nursery rhyme: “Sing a song of sixpence; a pocket full of rye; four and twenty blackbirds; baked in a pie…”) followed by CEDE (i.e. “allow”) and RESISTANCE (i.e. “opposition”).

across.text: No one more important than Cassius once?
across.explanation: THE GREATEST(i.e. “no one more important”). The remainder of the clue plays on a famous speech by heavyweight boxer Muhammad Ali, formerly “Cassius Clay”, about how he was the greatest. What I didn’t realise was he made a spoken word album of it in 1963.

across.text: Three or four days perhaps a short space to penetrate obscure knowledge
across.explanation: LONG WEEKEND(i.e. “three or four days perhaps”, considering bank holidays and Easter). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “obscure”) of KNOWLEDGE wrapped around or being “penetrated” by EN (i.e. “a short space”, specifically printer’s lingo for a space half the width of a lowercase ‘m’), like so: LONGWEEK(EN)D.

down.text: Operetta ticket costs around November said to fluctuate
down.explanation: PRINCESS IDA(i.e. “operetta” by Gilbert & Sullivan). Solution is PRICES (i.e. “ticket costs”) wrapped “around” N (“November” in the phonetic alphabet) and followed by an anagram (indicated by “to fluctuate”) of SAID, like so: PRI(N)CES-SIDA.

down.text: The end, in two languages, is delicate in another
down.explanation: ELFIN(i.e. “delicate”). Clue plays on how the solution, when written as EL FIN, is “the end” when expressed “in two languages”: EL being “the” in Spanish and FIN being “end” in French.

down.text: People being leaderless, competent king is creator of opportunities
down.explanation: ENABLER(i.e. “creator of opportunities”). Solution is MEN (i.e. “people”, or 48% of them anyway) with the first letter removed (indicated by “being leaderless”) and the remainder followed by ABLE (i.e. “competent”) and R (i.e. “king”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of the LatinRex), like so: EN-ABLE-R.

down.text: Fight’s ending with victory for Tweedledum – or Tweedledee?
down.explanation: TWIN(i.e. “Tweedledum – or Tweedledee”, identical twins from Lewis Carroll’sThrough The Looking Glass). Solution is T (i.e. “fight’s ending”, i.e. the last letter of “fight”) followed by WIN (i.e. “victory”).

down.text: Remarkably rare day round fireplace for head of gang
down.explanation: RINGLEADER(i.e. “head of gang”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “remarkably”) of RARE and D (a recognised abbreviation of “day”) wrapped “round” INGLE (i.e. Scots word for a “fireplace”), like so: R(INGLE)ADER.

down.text: Cleaner, or theatre ghost?
down.explanation: SURGICAL SPIRIT(i.e. “cleaner”). Clue plays on operating “theatres”, in which SURGERY is performed, and how “ghosts” are sometimes called SPIRITS. You get the idea.

down.text: Most general doubts are resolved after leaving university
down.explanation: BROADEST(i.e. “most general”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “resolved”) of DOUBTS ARE once the U has been removed (indicated by “after leaving university” – U being a recognised abbreviation of “university”).

down.text: Briefly, a storyteller’s other name
down.explanation: ALIAS(i.e. “other name”). Solution is A followed by LIAR (i.e. “storyteller”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “briefly”). The possessive ‘S is tacked on the end, like so: A-LIA-‘S.

down.text: Employee carries on, clean
down.explanation: WAGE SLAVE(i.e. “employee”). Solution is WAGES (i.e. “carries on”) followed by LAVE (i.e. an archaic word meaning to “clean”).

down.text: Drum almost filled with a fruit
down.explanation: TOMATO(i.e. “fruit”). Solution is TOMTOM (i.e. “drum”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “almost”) and the remainder wrapped around or “filled with” A, like so: TOM(A)TO.

down.text: Animal’s in group on the way out?
down.explanation: ENDANGERED SPECIES. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole, playing on how ENDANGERED can be described as being “on the way out”.

down.text: Profit from ID document, and betray trust
down.explanation: SELL THE PASS(i.e. “betray trust” – not a phrase I’ve come across before, but my Chambers backs it up). The first half of the clue pretty much sums up the solution as well.

down.text: Charlie committed too many tenants: one’s on the bed
down.explanation: COVERLET(i.e. “one’s on the bed”). Solution is C (“Charlie” in the phonetic alphabet) followed by OVERLET (i.e. “committed too many tenants”).

down.text: For example, Plato’s gall bladder problem that has a transforming effect?
down.explanation: PHILOSOPHER’S STONE(i.e. “that has a transforming effect”, a mythical compound sought by alchemists to turn some metals into gold). Solution is PHILOSOPHER’S (i.e. “for example, Plato’s” – other philosophers are available) followed by STONE (i.e. “gall bladder problem”).

down.text: Short performance by little creatures and big ones
down.explanation: GIANTS(i.e. “big ones”). Solution is GIG (i.e. “performance”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “short”) and the remainder followed by ANTS (i.e. “little creatures”), like so: GI-ANTS.

down.text: Wanting assistance from power in underworld, minutes away from tricky situation
down.explanation: HELPLESS(i.e. “wanting assistance”). Solution is P (a recognised abbreviation of “power”) placed “in” HELL (i.e. “underworld”) and followed by MESS (i.e. “tricky situation”) once the M has been removed (indicated by “minutes away from…” – M being a recognised abbreviation of “minutes”), like so: HEL(P)L-ESS.

down.text: Senior pupil hid lager to distribute
down.explanation: HEAD GIRL(i.e. “senior pupil”). “To distribute” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of HID LAGER.

down.text: Vehicle fitted with the one replacement body part that sparkles in its turn
down.explanation: CATHERINE WHEEL(i.e. a firework “that sparkles in its turn”). Solution is CAR (i.e. “vehicle”) wrapped around or “fitted with” THE and followed by I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and NEW HEEL (i.e. “replacement body part”), like so: CA(THE)R-I-NEW-HEEL.

down.text: In regular succession go off people, forgetting first name
down.explanation: ROTATION(i.e. “regular succession”). Solution is ROT (i.e. “go off”) followed by NATION (i.e. “people”) once the “first” N (a recognised abbreviation of “name”) has been removed or “forgotten”, like so: ROT-ATION.

down.text: Shown a card – taken
down.explanation: BOOKED. Solution satisfies “shown a card” in a number of sports, and “taken”.

down.text: Penniless, taking new courage, loving disaster?
down.explanation: BROKEN HEART(i.e. a “loving disaster”). Solution is BROKE (i.e. “penniless”) followed by N (a recognised abbreviation of “new”) and HEART (i.e. “courage”).

down.text: Really, really mean to take charge
down.explanation: SUPERINTEND(i.e. “to take charge”). When written as SUPER INTEND the solution also playfully satisfies “really, really mean to”.

down.text: Man of the cinema shot tennis, I see
down.explanation: SergeiEISENSTEIN(i.e. “man of the cinema”). “Shot” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TENNIS I SEE.

down.text: For Judith and others, a call father accepts with cry of delight
down.explanation: APOCRYPHA(i.e. “Judith and others”, a reference to books of The Bible). Solution is A followed by CRY (i.e. “call”) once placed in or “accepted” by POP (i.e. “father”, informally) and followed by HA (i.e. “cry of delight”), like so: A-PO(CRY)P-HA.

down.text: Being most stupid, is buried in wet earth
down.explanation: SILLIEST(i.e. “being most stupid”). Solution is LIES (i.e. “is buried” – think headstones) placed “in” SILT (i.e. “wet earth”), like so: SIL(LIES)T.

down.text: Writer leaves joint epistle unfinished
down.explanation: Sidonie-GabrielleCOLETTE(i.e. French “writer”. Search me). Solution is CO- (a prefix denoting “joint”) followed by LETTER (i.e. “epistle”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “unfinished”), like so: CO-LETTE. Another solved solely through the wordplay.

down.text: Long and very narrow lake I approach
down.explanation: LINEAR(i.e. “long and very narrow”). Solution is L (a recognised abbreviation of “lake”) followed by I and NEAR (i.e. “approach”).

down.text: Expression of delight about examiner’s last question
down.explanation: WHERE(i.e. a “question” – a bit too airy-fairy for me, but there you go). Solution is WHEE (i.e. “expression of delight”) wrapped “about” R (i.e. “examiner’s last” letter), like so: WHE(R)E.

down.text: Messy stuff runs out of some rock
down.explanation: GUNGE(i.e. “messy stuff”). Solution is GRUNGE (i.e. “some rock” music) with the R removed (indicated by “runs out of” – R being a recognised abbreviation of “runs” used in a number of ball games).

down.text: Inspection of car that is held
down.explanation: VIEW(i.e. “inspection”). Solution is VW (i.e. “car”, short for a Volkswagen) wrapped around or “holding” IE (i.e. “that is”, i.e. “i.e.”, short for the Latinid est), like so: V(IE)W.
